content.description: Starts with a cool, juggy overhang that leads into a chimney/stem box, then follows features up an incipient crack in a black streak. BIG stacked blocks at the end of the chimney section bring the quality down a notch, but the climbing is classic. Good route. Named after the nasty controlled burns/smoke and an enormous turkey I saw on the day of bolting.
content.location: Right side of wall. Look for steep chimney with black streak above.

content.description: Great steep route with a bouldery crux in the middle. Another classic climb that makes this tiny crag worthy.
content.location: Just right of Easy Skunkin'. Starts in steep scoop/dihedral.

content.description: A fun steep route with a definite crux past the 3rd bolt.
content.location: Left side of the bulging wall, to the right of Crackle - the short crack.

content.description: A long and challenging trad pitch that follows a rough looking crack in a right facing dihedral. It climbs much better than it looks. Do a little bulge move to gain the crack, then stem and jam for 50 feet to an easier finish. Holds hidden in the crack give relief to gobiphobia.
content.location: The dihedral formed by the bulging, overhanging wall and the main section of cliff.

content.description: Steep start with a couple cruxes on great holds in black and tan streaks, then fun climbing through flared and bubbly crack system that turns to a dihedral. Worth the drive by itself. Named after the skunks that live nearby.
content.location: Middle of the wall in tallest section with obvious black and tan water streaks in the start.

content.description: A short but steep crack problem on good stone.
content.location: Left of Pop(a 4 bolt 12a), on the left side of the bulging overhang.

content.description: Fun little route that pulls onto the right side of the bulge wall. Good warm up.
content.location: Right side of bulging wall. Climb up ledges to first bolt in the bulge.

content.description: The Balls Wall is a small south facing cliff located just a couple miles up FR 111. It's the "rock dike" as described in Tim Toula's directions to The Balls in A Cheap Way To Fly. It's likely that The Balls, the two mammoth boulders located beneath the road, trundled down over time from what I have now dubbed the Balls Wall, the first small cliff encountered as you ascend the mountain. The rock climbs well, offering mostly bolted face climbing, but there are a couple worthy cracks as well. The Balls Wall is your typical unimpressive looking cliff that offers surprisingly good rock and routes. Though small, it is worth a good day of climbing for the 5.11 leader.
